aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Analysis - Stits Playmate SA11A in Bridgeport, Texas
The accident occurred in Bridgeport, Texas.
The accident occurred on July 29, 2014, at 13:05 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Stits Playmate SA11A.
The Stits Playmate SA11A was built by William J Sutton.
The defining event was loss of control in flight.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was CEN14LA433.
The aircraft registration was N76WS.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
The pilot suffered no injuries.
The pilot refueled the airplane before the accident.
The wind direction at the airport changed about 90 degrees during the pilot's 30-minute stay.
The pilot reported wind speeds of 8 to 10 mph.
The pilot reported wind direction varying from 050 to 090 degrees.
The pilot chose runway 36 for departure.
The airplane made a descending left turn when it was about 10 to 15 feet above the ground.
The pilot stayed in the traffic pattern after the first incident.
The pilot landed on the runway after the first incident.
The pilot checked the flight controls after landing.
The flight controls appeared to respond correctly during the check.
The pilot departed again after checking the controls.
The airplane made another descending left turn after becoming airborne during the second takeoff.
The airplane did not respond to the pilot's control inputs during the second incident.
The pilot reduced power during the second incident.
The pilot landed in the grass near the runway during the second incident.
The airplane slid across a taxiway after landing in the grass.
The airplane impacted a tree at the airport perimeter.
The airplane impacted a fence at the airport perimeter.
Aileron control continuity was established during investigation.
No abnormalities were noted in the aileron controls.
The airport's automated weather reporting station reported calm wind.
The automated weather reporting station reported lightning in the distance south of the airport.
The airplane likely encountered rapidly changing wind conditions due to a nearby storm.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be the pilot's loss of airplane control during takeoff.
The loss of control occurred after encountering rapidly changing wind conditions.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Bridgeport, Texas

## Date & Time: 
July 29, 2014, 13:05 Local

## Aircraft:
SUTTON WILLIAM J STITS PLAYMATE SA11A

## Defining Event:
Loss of control in flight

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
CEN14LA433

## Registration:
N76WS

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis

After refueling the airplane, the pilot observed that the wind direction at the airport had changed about 90 degrees from when he had arrived about 30 minutes earlier. The pilot reported that the wind was now 8 to 10 mph and varying from 050 to 090 degrees, so he chose runway 36 for departure. When the airplane was about 10 to 15 ft above the ground, it made a descending left turn. The pilot stayed in the traffic pattern and then landed on the runway. The pilot checked the flight controls, and they appeared to respond correctly. He departed again, and, after becoming airborne, the airplane made another descending left turn. The airplane did not respond to the pilot's control inputs, so he reduced power and landed in the grass near the runway. The airplane slid across a taxiway and impacted a tree and fence at the airport perimeter. Aileron control continuity was established with no abnormalities noted. The airport's automated weather reporting station reported calm wind and lightning in the distance south of the airport about the time of departure. Based on the events, it's likely that, during the takeoff, the airplane encountered rapidly changing wind conditions due to a nearby storm.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

The pilot's loss of airplane control during takeoff after encountering rapidly changing wind conditions.

---
